without getting into too much detail of what SPI is it's it's just another communication protocol like the the async serial protocol and the logic
analyzer has a uh an analyzer to decode this data so these these points are the
key things to understanding on how you would be able to decode that data uh that I saw on these wires first is that
SPI has the ability to transmit data up to 100 MHz in speed so the first thing I
had to do was increase the speed of my logic analyzer sample rate uh the logic
the the actual Hardware has limitations on how fast it can actually sample things but you can configure the
software to sample things quicker with less pins being connected to it since I only had three pins uh I was able to
sample at 50 MHz so I had to to accept a risk that Poss it's possible that the
data that I was getting is not going to be anything because I wasn't able to sample fast enough um next is that SPI
communicates in a Master Slave mode and there's the ability to have multiple slaves so you can actually have multiple
chips communicating over one specific uh debug pad output uh there's four lines
in SPI the MOSI which is Master output slave input I always look at things from
the perspective of the master so and I just call that output Master input slave output which is put to the master and
then there's an enable or slave select line which will basically determine what slave you're communicating with uh when
you're actually sending data or retrieving data uh and finally there's a clock pin and so in in the acing serial
the clock was at that specific B rate that's that's when it knew when to sample things with SPI the clock is not
like a metronome clock uh it works in one of two different um variations when
the clock pin goes from high to low it will sample other other two pins the output or the input or vice versa when
the uh clock goes from low to high it'll sample the other two pins and say and so at that point in time when the clock pin
changes what is what are the the output and the input pins at either a one or a zero or a high or a low um after fig
after reading all this and understanding more about SPI you can see zoomed in you you can tell that that brown number one
is the clock pin and it's going at 16 different up and downs through each blob
uh then the the next one was the master output and the following one was the master

the JTAG ports and that's what actually will determine if pin should be transmitting or receiving data so you

be triggering this clock up and down um so then from there there's five pins
that uh that need to be connected the vref TMS tck tdo and TDI

which is called J they're they're called that and if there are multiple devices multiple chips connected to one pin out

connected to this daisy chain is called a tap which is going to be important when trigging the software so first thing I
had to do was find a u JTAG cable that I could use uh I ended up purchasing this
